body.text1: Si­murgh is a co­los­sal bird in the my­thol­o­gy of the Ira­ni­an peoples. The or­i­gin of the name can be traced back to its Aves­tan roots, specif­i­cal­ly to the term ê¨®ê¨Üê¨≠ê¨Üê¨ñê¨ã‚∏±ê¨Øê¨Äê¨âê¨•ê¨ã (m…ôr…ôŒ≥≈ç saƒìn≈ç), which trans­lates to "the bird Saƒìna," mean­ing an

tooltip1.text: Also, in San&shyskrit the word ≈õyen√° means a fal&shycon or an eagle<sup>1</sup>

body.text2: . In the Pah­la­vi language, it is re­ferred to as "sƒìnmurw," while in Sog­di­an, it takes the form of "synmrŒ≥."1,2 The ver­sion in use is in the New Per­sian, and the name can be bro­ken down in­to two words "si" ‚Äî mean­ing thir­ty and "

tooltip2.text: In con&shytem&shypo&shyrary Ta&shyjiki, the word means a chick&shyen, but in po&shyet&shyry it can mean both

body.text3: " ‚Äî bird. How&shyever, num&shyber thir&shyty had no di&shyrect con&shynec&shytion to the orig&shyi&shynal es&shysence of the crea&shyture until the Islamic period (ex&shyplained be&shylow).

slides.info: Recreation of Simurgh from "SƒÅm Returns with his Son ZƒÅl". Illuminated folio from ShƒÅh Tahmasp ShƒÅhnƒÅma, circa 1525-1530. Tabriz, Iran<sup>3</sup>

body.text1:
Si­murgh is de­scribed as a com­pos­ite crea­ture ‚Äî with a pea­cock tail, falcon body, a dog's head and li­on claws.2
In

tooltip1.text: From Pahlavi meaning "Primal Creation." It discusses the universe's origin, including its fauna and flora, from a Zoroastrian viewpoint<sup>http://www.avesta.org/mp/bundahis.html</sup>

body.text2:
13.10, Saƒìna is categorized as a bird and depicted with a distinctive trait: three fingers.http://www.avesta.org/mp/grb12.htm#chap13 This feature appears unconventional for a bird, given that most avian species, with the exception of ostriches, have four claws. She is thought to be gi­gan­tic, with the ca­pac­i­ty to car­ry an ele­phant or a whale. The sweep of her wings could dis­perse the clouds and cast a shad­ow so im­mense that it ri­valed the size of moun­tains.
In some ver­sions, Si­murgh is de­scribed with a hu­man head and fe­male breasts, and even in the other ver­sions, it is de­pic­ted as a fe­male bird. According to an ancient Mittani tale, Simurgh lived for 1700 years before bursting into flames and is rebornhttps://www.worldanvil.com/w/alam-cranial/a/simurgh-article ‚Äî much like the Greek Phoenix. Her feathers are copper-colored, and it harbors a deep dislike for snakes, similar to the Buddhist and Hindu

tooltip2.text: In Sogdian Buddhist texts, the term "garuda" is translated as "synmrŒ≥."<sup>Utz, p. 14</sup>

body.text3: . Al&shyso, she is be&shylieved to have heal&shying pow&shyers and im&shymor&shytal&shyi&shyty, having wit&shynessed the world's de&shystruc&shytion and re&shybirth three times, gain&shying wis&shydom span&shyning all ages, past and fu&shyture.

Garuda carrying an elephant <sup>Fig - Birla Razmnama</sup>

Miniature painting of "Garuda Caught an Elephant and a Tortoise". From RazmnƒÅma ("The Book of War"). 17th century. Mughal India. <sup>https://www.alamy.com/painting-of-razmnama-garuda-vishnus-eagle-want-to-amrita-to-free-his-mother-kadru-so-in-his-way-he-hungry-and-caught-elephant-and-tortoise-who-are-ascetic-vibhavasu-and-supratika-who-are-cursed-by-sages-when-garuda-sit-on-tree-for-rest-and-eat-them-sudden-branch-of-tree-about-crack-garuda-see-balkhilya-hanging-down-on-tree-branch-for-tapasya-so-he-hold-branch-in-his-beak-paintings-of-razmnama-is-the-persian-translation-of-one-of-the-great-hindu-epics-of-india-the-mahabharata-the-mughal-emperor-akbar-took-a-personal-interest-in-the-translation-project-and-invited-learned-men-and-image187449475.html</sup>

body.text1: As the name implies, the earliest reference to Simurgh, or more accurately Saƒìna, is found in the Avesta, the sacred text of Zoroastrianism. In

tooltip1.text:
Yashts are a collection of hymns dedicated to yazatas (angels) and ancient heroes.
Rashn(u) Yasht is dedicated to Rashn(u) ‚Äî an angel of justice

body.text2:
, verse 17, the following is mentioned:
Whether thou, O holy Rashn(u)! art on the tree of the eagle (sa√™na), that stands in the middle of the sea Vouru-Kasha, that is called the tree of good remedies, the tree of powerful remedies, the tree of all remedies, and on which rest the seeds of all plants; we invoke, we bless Rashn(u), the strong. I invoke his friendship towards this var prepared...http://www.avesta.org/ka/yt12sbe.htm
This "tree of the eagle" is named Gaokerena, also known as a Tree of Life is a variant of the white Haoma treeProceedings of Armenian-Iranian Astronomical Workshop (AIAW), held 13-16 October 2015 in Byurakan Astrophysical Observatory, Armenia. Eds.: A. M. Mickaelian, H. G. Khosroshahi, H. A. Harutyunian. Yerevan, "Gitutyun" Publishing House of the National Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Armenia (NAS RA), p. 248-252. According to Zoroastrian beliefs, Saƒìna's nest is on this tree, and the tree is a potent medicine, all-healing and contained the seeds of all Earth's plants.http://www.avesta.org/mp/bundahis.html#chapter18 .9 chapter 9.5, 27.4 When the Saƒìna ascended, its powerful flight shook the tree so violently that the seeds scattered worldwide, leading to the growth of all known plant species.https://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/simorgThe Simurgh was believed to

tooltip2.text: Withers the tree, associating her with the sun

body.text3: the land and waters, hence bestow fertility.

slides.info: Suzani with two peacock-like birds (possibly simurgh) around the "tree of life." From Bukhara, Uzbekistan. Early 20th century. Suzani Museum.<sup>http://www.suzanimuseum.com/?page=5</sup>
Embroidered bridal veil with simurghs around the "tree of life." From DarvƒÅz, Tajikistan<sup>https://search.rsl.ru/ru/record/01007044109</sup>

body.text1:
After Islamization, Simurgh loses its sacred status but continues to exist in arts, folklore, and lit­er­a­ture.
In Rudaki's rendition of Pa√±chatantra, known as Kalila wa-Dimna in Perso-Arabic, there is a fable about Simurgh. In this tale, Simurgh is portrayed as a kind and honest king of birds. For example, it narrates how Simurgh rescues the chicks of a bird named Taitoo from a river monster:
...PodshƒÅh Simurgh, daryoro biburd,
Khonayo bacha bad-on Taitoo supurd...c

King Simurgh, on the sea's vast spree,
Returned the home and kids to Taitoo with glee.
body.text2: In Fer­daw­si's ShƒÅh­nƒÅ­ma, the Simurgh is the guardian and teacher to ZƒÅl.

tooltip1.text:
The word "zƒÅl" literally means "an albino."
In Tajiki, it can also refer to a plant that has lost its green pigment

body.text3: born with albinism, is rejected by his father, King SƒÅm, who sees his features as the work of Ahriman. King SƒÅm leaves him in the Alburz mountains. Simurgh finds the child, cares for him, and raises him, imparting much of her wisdom. When ZƒÅl wants to return to his father, Si¬≠murgh gives him three feathers. He can burn one to summon her for help. ZƒÅl uses a feather during his wife's difficult labor, and Si¬≠murgh assists in delivering the child through a cesarean. This child is Rustam, the main hero of ShƒÅh¬≠nƒÅ¬≠ma, and Si¬≠murgh becomes his guardian, aiding him in battles.https://vk.com/doc279783865_546662542?hash=vEJlsJJuNEJO4TrkXxAw7f0wbrIQIk4NZVlo1ixXTyg
body.text4: Shihab al-Din Suhrawardi, the founder of the IshrƒÅqi ("Illuminationism") school in Islamic philosophy, extensively incorporated Zoroastrian symbols to explain Islamic concepts. One of his Persian works, Safir-i Simurgh ("The Calling of the Simurgh"), discusses
